Examples

Ivan Jacob Agaloos Pesigan

2021-03-21

Source: vignettes/examples.Rmd
examples.Rmd

This vignette presents four examples of generating Monte Carlo confidence intervals using the semmci package. The first example involves a simple mediation model. The second example involves a serial mediation model. The third example involves missing data. The fourth example involves the standardized indirect effect in a simple mediation model.

library(semmcci)
#> 
#> Attaching package: 'semmcci'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     print
library(lavaan)
#> This is lavaan 0.6-8
#> lavaan is FREE software! Please report any bugs.

Example 1: The Simple Mediation Model

This is an example of a simple mediation model where x is the predictor, m is the mediator, and y is the dependent variable.

Data

n <- 1000
x <- rnorm(n = n)
m <- 0.50 * x + rnorm(n = n)
y <- 0.25 * x + 0.50 * m + rnorm(n = n)
data <- data.frame(x, m, y)

Model Specification

The indirect effect is defined by the product of the slopes of paths x to m labeled as a and m to y labeled as b. In this example, we are interested in the confidence intervals of ab defined as the product of a and b using the := operator in the lavaan model syntax.

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b * m
  m ~ a * x
  indirect := a * b
  direct := cp
  total := cp + (a * b)
"

Model Fitting

We can now fit the model using the sem function from lavaan.

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 12 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         5
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Expected
#>   Information saturated (h1) model          Structured
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.221    0.036    6.209    0.000
#>     m          (b)    0.505    0.033   15.377    0.000
#>   m ~                                                 
#>     x          (a)    0.467    0.031   15.113    0.000
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 0.997    0.045   22.361    0.000
#>    .m                 0.925    0.041   22.361    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     indirect          0.236    0.022   10.779    0.000
#>     direct            0.221    0.036    6.209    0.000
#>     total             0.457    0.036   12.797    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

The fit lavaan object can then be passed to the mc function from semmcci to generate Monte Carlo confidence intervals for defined parameters.

out <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
print(out)
#> Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>             est     se   R ci_0.05 ci_0.5 ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp       0.2209 0.0307 100  0.1342 0.1432 0.1583  0.2727  0.2860   0.2926
#> b        0.5051 0.0287 100  0.4296 0.4338 0.4571  0.5612  0.5761   0.5828
#> a        0.4672 0.0337 100  0.3843 0.3844 0.4005  0.5208  0.5361   0.5465
#> y~~y     0.9974 0.0429 100  0.8984 0.9003 0.9168  1.0781  1.1009   1.1078
#> m~~m     0.9245 0.0384 100  0.8328 0.8364 0.8590  1.0019  1.0288   1.0500
#> x~~x     0.9674     NA  NA      NA     NA     NA      NA      NA       NA
#> indirect 0.2360 0.0197 100  0.1795 0.1823 0.1936  0.2660  0.2744   0.2762
#> direct   0.2209 0.0307 100  0.1342 0.1432 0.1583  0.2727  0.2860   0.2926
#> total    0.4569 0.0321 100  0.3850 0.3867 0.3911  0.5077  0.5265   0.5366

Example 2: The Serial Mediation Model

This is an example of a serial mediation model with two mediators where x is the predictor, m1 is the first mediator, m2 is the second mediator, and y is the dependent variable.

Data

n <- 1000
x <- rnorm(n = n)
m1 <- 0.50 * x + rnorm(n = n)
m2 <- 0.15 * x + 0.50 * m1 + rnorm(n = n)
y <- 0.10 * x + 0.05 * m1 + 0.50 * m2 + rnorm(n = n)
data <- data.frame(x, m1, m2, y)

Model Specification

We can define several indirect effects in this example:

  • \(x \rightarrow m1 \rightarrow m2 \rightarrow y\)
  • \(x \rightarrow m1 \rightarrow m2\)
  • \(x \rightarrow m1 \rightarrow y\)
  • \(m1 \rightarrow m2 \rightarrow y\)

These indirect effects are defined using the := operator in the lavaan model syntax.

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b1 * m1 + b2 * m2
  m2 ~ a2 * x + k * m1
  m1 ~ a1 * x
  # x -> m1 -> m2 -> y
  a1kb2 := a1 * k * b2
  # x -> m1 -> m2
  a1k := a1 * k
  # x -> m1 -> y
  a2b2 := a2 * b2
  # m1 -> m2 -> y
  kb2 := k * b2
"

Model Fitting

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 15 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         9
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Expected
#>   Information saturated (h1) model          Structured
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.065    0.036    1.811    0.070
#>     m1        (b1)    0.038    0.034    1.094    0.274
#>     m2        (b2)    0.507    0.031   16.382    0.000
#>   m2 ~                                                
#>     x         (a2)    0.183    0.036    5.031    0.000
#>     m1         (k)    0.463    0.032   14.533    0.000
#>   m1 ~                                                
#>     x         (a1)    0.512    0.032   15.875    0.000
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 0.992    0.044   22.361    0.000
#>    .m2                1.033    0.046   22.361    0.000
#>    .m1                1.020    0.046   22.361    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     a1kb2             0.120    0.013    8.970    0.000
#>     a1k               0.237    0.022   10.719    0.000
#>     a2b2              0.093    0.019    4.810    0.000
#>     kb2               0.235    0.022   10.871    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

# The argument `par = TRUE` can be specified to use multiple cores for a faster implementation.
# The number of cores to use can be specified with `ncores`.
out <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
print(out)
#> Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>           est     se   R ci_0.05  ci_0.5  ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp     0.0653 0.0396 100 -0.0078 -0.0071  0.0009  0.1501  0.1570   0.1609
#> b1     0.0376 0.0298 100 -0.0363 -0.0358 -0.0220  0.0900  0.1021   0.1065
#> b2     0.5075 0.0303 100  0.4308  0.4357  0.4518  0.5654  0.5707   0.5710
#> a2     0.1830 0.0385 100  0.0998  0.1037  0.1172  0.2602  0.2871   0.2988
#> k      0.4626 0.0316 100  0.3884  0.3902  0.3979  0.5181  0.5433   0.5472
#> a1     0.5125 0.0318 100  0.4422  0.4443  0.4502  0.5728  0.5983   0.6089
#> y~~y   0.9916 0.0456 100  0.8812  0.8855  0.8970  1.0805  1.1055   1.1096
#> m2~~m2 1.0334 0.0454 100  0.8969  0.9101  0.9379  1.1130  1.1343   1.1409
#> m1~~m1 1.0198 0.0472 100  0.8796  0.8950  0.9269  1.1045  1.1147   1.1170
#> x~~x   0.9785     NA  NA      NA      NA      NA      NA      NA       NA
#> a1kb2  0.1203 0.0125 100  0.0892  0.0913  0.0955  0.1450  0.1615   0.1695
#> a1k    0.2371 0.0202 100  0.1775  0.1812  0.2006  0.2750  0.2917   0.3021
#> a2b2   0.0928 0.0202 100  0.0526  0.0541  0.0599  0.1382  0.1507   0.1570
#> kb2    0.2348 0.0197 100  0.1876  0.1919  0.2007  0.2734  0.2861   0.2903

Example 3: Missing Data

This is an example of a simple mediation model with missing data.

Data

n <- 1000
x <- rnorm(n = n)
m <- 0.50 * x + rnorm(n = n)
y <- 0.25 * x + 0.50 * m + rnorm(n = n)
data <- data.frame(x, m, y)

# Create data set with missing values.

miss <- sample(1:dim(data)[1], 300)
data[miss[1:100], "x"] <- NA
data[miss[101:200], "m"] <- NA
data[miss[201:300], "y"] <- NA

Model Specification

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b * m
  m ~ a * x
  ab := a * b
"

Model Fitting

We are using missing = "fiml" to handle missing data in lavaan. Since there are missing values in x, we also set fixed.x = FALSE.

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model,
  missing = "fiml",
  fixed.x = FALSE
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 14 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         9
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>   Number of missing patterns                         4
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Observed
#>   Observed information based on                Hessian
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.242    0.040    6.113    0.000
#>     m          (b)    0.558    0.034   16.564    0.000
#>   m ~                                                 
#>     x          (a)    0.531    0.034   15.575    0.000
#> 
#> Intercepts:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 0.029    0.034    0.853    0.394
#>    .m                 0.045    0.035    1.313    0.189
#>     x                -0.005    0.034   -0.139    0.890
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 1.004    0.049   20.593    0.000
#>    .m                 1.077    0.051   20.924    0.000
#>     x                 1.070    0.050   21.309    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     ab                0.296    0.026   11.405    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

# The argument `par = TRUE` can be specified to use multiple cores for a faster implementation.
# The number of cores to use can be specified with `ncores`.
out <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
print(out)
#> Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>          est     se   R ci_0.05  ci_0.5  ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp    0.2423 0.0378 100  0.1495  0.1550  0.1707  0.3174  0.3327   0.3359
#> b     0.5576 0.0355 100  0.4711  0.4767  0.4879  0.6228  0.6346   0.6370
#> a     0.5310 0.0344 100  0.4632  0.4634  0.4713  0.6072  0.6185   0.6240
#> y~~y  1.0037 0.0476 100  0.8994  0.9051  0.9123  1.0853  1.0975   1.0983
#> m~~m  1.0765 0.0529 100  0.9718  0.9728  0.9752  1.1582  1.1805   1.1965
#> x~~x  1.0703 0.0479 100  0.9487  0.9492  0.9778  1.1591  1.1803   1.1913
#> y~1   0.0291 0.0327 100 -0.0769 -0.0646 -0.0404  0.0804  0.0932   0.0958
#> m~1   0.0454 0.0338 100 -0.0311 -0.0283 -0.0177  0.1045  0.1133   0.1143
#> x~1  -0.0047 0.0393 100 -0.1046 -0.1020 -0.0806  0.0685  0.0832   0.0894
#> ab    0.2961 0.0268 100  0.2372  0.2393  0.2497  0.3525  0.3752   0.3841

Example 4.a: The Standardized Simple Mediation Model - Version a

In this example, confidence intervals for the standardized indirect effect are generated using std.

Data

n <- 1000
x <- rnorm(n = n)
m <- 0.50 * x + rnorm(n = n)
y <- 0.25 * x + 0.50 * m + rnorm(n = n)
data <- data.frame(x, m, y)

Model Specification

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b * m
  m ~ a * x
  indirect := a * b
  direct := cp
  total := cp + (a * b)
"

Model Fitting

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model,
  fixed.x = FALSE
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 12 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         6
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Expected
#>   Information saturated (h1) model          Structured
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.183    0.036    5.054    0.000
#>     m          (b)    0.511    0.032   15.863    0.000
#>   m ~                                                 
#>     x          (a)    0.540    0.031   17.264    0.000
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>    .y                 1.022    0.046   22.361    0.000
#>    .m                 0.984    0.044   22.361    0.000
#>     x                 1.006    0.045   22.361    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     indirect          0.276    0.024   11.681    0.000
#>     direct            0.183    0.036    5.054    0.000
#>     total             0.459    0.036   12.888    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

# The argument `par = TRUE` can be specified to use multiple cores for a faster implementation
# for both `mc` and `std`.
# The number of cores to use can be specified with `ncores`.
mc <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
out <- std(mc)
print(out)
#> Standardized Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>             est     se   R ci_0.05 ci_0.5 ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp       0.1507 0.0298 100  0.0683 0.0749 0.0862  0.2038  0.2093   0.2117
#> b        0.4731 0.0260 100  0.4139 0.4163 0.4221  0.5286  0.5381   0.5426
#> a        0.4792 0.0278 100  0.4180 0.4201 0.4262  0.5283  0.5323   0.5345
#> y~~y     0.6852 0.0287 100  0.6070 0.6075 0.6262  0.7371  0.7385   0.7390
#> m~~m     0.7704 0.0315 100  0.6951 0.6998 0.7167  0.8311  0.8385   0.8399
#> x~~x     1.0000 0.0406 100  0.8772 0.8873 0.9284  1.0833  1.0994   1.1064
#> indirect 0.2267 0.0177 100  0.1848 0.1901 0.1966  0.2603  0.2703   0.2724
#> direct   0.1507 0.0298 100  0.0683 0.0749 0.0862  0.2038  0.2093   0.2117
#> total    0.3774 0.0298 100  0.3070 0.3085 0.3193  0.4296  0.4325   0.4339

Example 4.b: The Standardized Simple Mediation Model - Version b

In this example, confidence intervals for the standardized indirect effect are generated by specifying the standardized indirect effect as a derived parameter using the := operator.

Model Specification

The standardized indirect effect in a simple mediation model involves paths \(a\), and \(b\), and the standard deviations of \(x\) and \(y\). It is given by

\[\begin{equation} a b \frac{s_x}{s_y} \end{equation}\]

where

\[\begin{equation} s_x = \sqrt{ s_{x}^{2} } \end{equation}\]

and

\[\begin{equation} s_y = \sqrt{ c^{\prime 2} s_{x}^{2} + a^2 b^2 s_{x}^{2} + b^2 s_{e_{m}}^{2} + 2 c^{\prime} b a s_{x}^{2} + s_{e_{y}}^{2} } \end{equation}\]

where

\(s_{e_{y}}^{2}\) and \(s_{e_{m}}^{2}\) are the residual variances in the regression equations.

The standardized indirect effect can be defined using the := operator and the named parameters in the model.

model <- "
  y ~ cp * x + b * m
  m ~ a * x
  x ~~ var_x * x
  m ~~ var_em * m
  y ~~ var_ey * y
  std := a * b * (sqrt(var_x) / sqrt(cp^2 * var_x + a^2 * b^2 * var_x + b^2 * var_em + 2 * cp * b * a * var_x + var_ey))
"

Model Fitting

fit <- sem(
  data = data,
  model = model,
  fixed.x = FALSE
)
summary(fit)
#> lavaan 0.6-8 ended normally after 14 iterations
#> 
#>   Estimator                                         ML
#>   Optimization method                           NLMINB
#>   Number of model parameters                         6
#>                                                       
#>   Number of observations                          1000
#>                                                       
#> Model Test User Model:
#>                                                       
#>   Test statistic                                 0.000
#>   Degrees of freedom                                 0
#> 
#> Parameter Estimates:
#> 
#>   Standard errors                             Standard
#>   Information                                 Expected
#>   Information saturated (h1) model          Structured
#> 
#> Regressions:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>   y ~                                                 
#>     x         (cp)    0.183    0.036    5.054    0.000
#>     m          (b)    0.511    0.032   15.863    0.000
#>   m ~                                                 
#>     x          (a)    0.540    0.031   17.264    0.000
#> 
#> Variances:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     x       (vr_x)    1.006    0.045   22.361    0.000
#>    .m       (vr_m)    0.984    0.044   22.361    0.000
#>    .y       (vr_y)    1.022    0.046   22.361    0.000
#> 
#> Defined Parameters:
#>                    Estimate  Std.Err  z-value  P(>|z|)
#>     std               0.227    0.018   12.657    0.000

Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals

# The argument `par = TRUE` can be specified to use multiple cores for a faster implementation.
# The number of cores to use can be specified with `ncores`.
out <- mc(
  fit,
  R = 100L, # use a large value e.g., 20000L for actual research
  alpha = c(0.001, 0.01, 0.05)
)
print(out)
#> Monte Carlo Confidence Intervals
#>           est     se   R ci_0.05 ci_0.5 ci_2.5 ci_97.5 ci_99.5 ci_99.95
#> cp     0.1835 0.0331 100  0.0794 0.0979 0.1252  0.2392  0.2480   0.2481
#> b      0.5111 0.0330 100  0.4314 0.4338 0.4412  0.5660  0.5895   0.5950
#> a      0.5399 0.0302 100  0.4532 0.4649 0.4866  0.6004  0.6116   0.6119
#> var_x  1.0064 0.0449 100  0.8860 0.8990 0.9255  1.0908  1.1113   1.1151
#> var_em 0.9844 0.0402 100  0.9023 0.9033 0.9145  1.0683  1.0880   1.0980
#> var_ey 1.0220 0.0466 100  0.9273 0.9283 0.9315  1.1125  1.1410   1.1569
#> std    0.2267 0.0182 100  0.1847 0.1854 0.1920  0.2601  0.2651   0.2675
